They asked us about our airport transportation during checked in and when i told them i took the limo bus from the airport they asked my flight details on my way back to the USA and booked our seat right away without us asking. The GM and their team were so nice and very polite. Great selection for the breakfast buffet.In overall i was very happy with my stay at Cerulean, will diff come back again.Note : I am not sure how to rate the room rate, some people might find this hotel is within mid range and some find it luxury.

We booked a twin beds room and it is enough for my family with 2 children, 5 and 8 years old. This hotel is 5 mins walk to Shibuya Crossing and there are many restaurants nearby. A small supermarket just around the corner under a bridge. We were glad to be upgraded to a cornor room where the bathtub is beside a large window. My kids enjoyed the bathtub the most. We didnt try breakfast. Guests need to pay to enter swimming pool therefore we didnt use it.All in all, good location and friendly staff.

Great convenient location - 5 min walk to Shibuya station which is really convenient to lots of lines. (Shinjuku is also really convenient but felt way more crowded - like Times Sq before the pedestrian areas) (7-Eleven downstairs in the building)Rooms are modern and clean. Unfortunately, my husband and two kids had to split into two rooms because two double bed configurations don't exist but they did give us two joining rooms which was nice but not very economical for us. The hotel itself does not have a lot of personality - felt like a nice business hotel that could be anywhere in the world. So here's the most interesting part of our stay - we were there during a 6.9 magnitude earthquake. Being from CA, I am not particularly afraid of earthquakes but being in a high rise during one is a whole new experience. I think the buildings are meant to move with the quake so an already long earthquake was made extra lengthy. I woke up at 5 am and it felt like I was on a Caribbean booze cruise. The rolling went on so long that I scanned the room for potential falling items (absolutely nothing), checked on my kids in the next room(still asleep) and looked out the window (locals walking to work totally chill) and we were still rolling. When I opened the door, we found crazed Americans running around heading for the stairs so we decided better safe than sorry although by then the movement had stopped. After grabbing our kids and trudging down 31 flights, the hotel staff kindly told us we were safe and could head back to our room in the elevator or hang out in the lobby if we felt more comfortable - with a gentle reminder that they do have alarms if we actually needed to evacuate. I noticed we lost my daughters sneaker at some point and asked a staff member to keep an eye out for it. We quickly went back to our room and back to bed. Five hours later we get a call that the staff had searched the lobby and all the stairwells for the missing sneaker with apologies that they could not locate it anywhere but they would continue to search and wanted to know our exact path downstairs. A quick search in our room revealed it was behind our door. Oops. (Don't worry, we quickly called back to call off the search) Tldr- that building is earthquake safe and service is almost too good!

Was in Tokyo for work and stayed here due to the proximity of the hotel to our work venue, but I would say that this is also a good location to stay if you're travelling for leisure, especially for those who would like to do a substantial bit of shopping. It's a 5-10 min walk to Shibuya, and just a couple of stations away from Shinjuku which makes it very conveniently located. Access to the airport is also very convenient - can either take the airport bus or the JR line (JR Shibuya station is just a 5 mins walk from the hotel).The rooms and bathroom were clean and nice, and by Asian standards, also very spacious, so it was a very comfortable stay. Was working from the hotel room most of the time, so didn't get housekeeping to come in and clean the room, but they were quite prompt in bringing amenities whenever requested.

Firstly, we did not have a great experience upon check-in at the hotel which did dampen our excitement of staying here. We had already stayed in other hotels in Tokyo and this one was by far the most expensive and so we had prepared ourselves for a bit of luxury however it hardly met that expectation and the front desk staff did not provide the warm welcome weary travelers were looking for - it did seem the hotel catered mostly to business guests so perhaps the service style wasn't quite what we were accustomed to. Without going into the ins and outs of our check-in woes, we were informed that we had been upgraded rooms as they had oversold the standard room we had booked and we would be given a key card to access our floor from the elevator - it was highlighted to us we could not use any amenity afforded to those who had booked the more expensive rooms and that it was an upgrade in room only which was fine for us, we would have been happy with the room we booked.Anyway, our 'upgraded' room did not seem to have anything extra over and above a standard room and the only positive I can give is that it was large for Tokyo hotel room standards however still small and not exactly spacious. Cleanliness was okay and comfort was so-so, however having stayed in comparable hotels in other areas of Japan (such as Osaka) this hotel was severely lacking. I understand Osaka and Tokyo are completely different cities, however the idea of a luxury hotel in Tokyo is completely different from Osaka and this hotel did feel rather basic, but with a large price tag and they had completely neglected the small details that make an expensive stay at a premium hotel worthwhile. The restaurants and bars located inside the hotel were absolutely extortionate and room service prices were actually pretty comical which placed dining or drinking inside the hotel way out of our budget - had there been at least one affordable option we may have dined in. The location is pretty good in terms of transport, shopping and dining, however I did much prefer staying in the Shinjuku area - but that is just personal preference, there was more that appealed to us in Shinjuku than Shibuya. Overall, I personally think the hotel is overpriced for what they deliver and that there are more affordable hotels in the area that offer the same standard as the Cerulean Tower does and the customer service is hardly a redeeming feature of the hotel - we experienced far better in other hotels in Tokyo, many much cheaper than the stay we booked here.

Whenever I book this hotel for business purpose, I'm very worried about potential consequence that might be caused by hotel. Sometimes they miss booking note on their desk, so that my guest will be putted back for the confirmation of booking, which takes long.Simply as their system is out-dated, or maybe just laziness, everything takes longer than I expect. When I ask something to concierge and desk for confirmation, they are always afraid of being accused, or gives me skeptical glance with the atmosphere of "defense".Japan is not the place to do legal fight, not quite sure why they are not so confident as staffs for luxury hotels.If you don't mind about cost and location, I'd suggest Grand Hyatt Roppongi or Park Hyatt Shinjuku, you'd better to have better experience. Or there are many good hotels in east side of central Tokyo, such as Imperial Hotel, Conrad, or Hoshinoya in Marunouchi and so on.In coming years, there will be new hotel in Shibuya under luxury label, or some independent brand comes. I really want this hotel survive, but want them to learn what the luxury service is under competition.

This hotel is four to five stars. Great loc tion just above the famous Shibuya crossing and Shibuya Mark City station. Also a main city stop for the airport bus service. All in all its convenient and well appointed. The staff were friendly and professional. I'd say its worth the price to stay there. Not cheap of course but nothing in Tokyo is. At least here you c n see the value and convenience you get. Tips. Early morning walking or jogging. Go to an zing Yoyogi park. 1.5 km from the hotel. Its truly beautiful and next to the 1964 Tokyo Olympics site. So quite interesting and lovely. Shopping tip. After wandering Shibuya walk to Omutesando area. Only ten more minutes and lots of quite streets and fashionable little shops. As well As big brand stores. ROOM TIP. 3113 with views over Shibuya. Some rooms will face towards Mt Fuji.

We booked two rooms for the family and stayed for three nights in August. Rooms and bathrooms were spacious and clean. Beds are extremely comfortable. Service is friendly and accommodating. The view is spectacular. The buffet breakfast downstairs is delicious. The metro is within very easy walking distance.

The Cerulean Tower is perhaps not as iconic as the Park Hyatt (Lost in Translation), but it is an equally impressive and modern building at the heart of Shibuya. The rooms are spacious, with large windows, and the service is impeccable. Even if you don't get a room at the very top, you can always have a drink at the 40th floor bar.

We stayed in the Cerulean Hotel when visiting Tokyo for the snow and was incredibly happy with the hotel. Fantastic room, possibly the biggest we've stayed in for Tokyo, and the bathroom was almost as big as the room! We enjoyed the Iron Chef restaurant below, with front row seats to the magic! The room was incredibly appointed, with comfortable beds, great amenities and thoughtful touches to the setting.

We stayed at the Cerulean Hotel for three days while visiting Tokyo and thoroughly enjoyed the fine service and facilities. Breakfast was included in our booking and there was an excellent buffet with a wide selection of Asian and western food. We also had afternoon tea at the main restaurant one day and it was delicious.The hotel was less than a ten minute walk from a subway station so that getting to various Tokyo sights was easy.

We had a Nice stay. Great location. Ask for free pool pas. We got them for 3 days and We appriciated it very much. We also paid for upgrates to lounge area and loved this tooWe will come back. Even If this is not a cheap stay

Only stayed one night but it was a great room, a great view and an ever better view from the top floor bar 40 floors up. Try the Japanese wines. Very good Excellent breakfast too. Early morning walk to the Meiji shrine too

This hotel is overall one of the best I used for a business trip.Perfectly located in Shibuya, this hotel has amazing facilities as restaurants (Japanese, Chinese, Italian, etc), a gym and a beautiful pool.Easy access to public transport and airport buses and to shopping.I love it!

A great hotel to stay at. Stayed 6 nights. This is my second time staying at Cerulean. Have enjoyed my stay both times. The rooms are a good size with great views over Shibuya and Tokyo. Very convenient to the night life, railway station and shopping complexes. Staff are very helpful and friendly. Food in the restaurants is excellent. Level 40 is worth a visit !

We just return from a week in Tokyo that kicked off with a stay at Park Hyatt. After two nights, we decided to move on because of the inconvenient location to the metro. In Tokyo, you NEED the metro. We arrived at the hotel around noon and were planning to ask if they would hold out bags until check in began at 3. We were pleasantly surprised when Cerulean front desk upgraded our room to a corner room and the hospitality was on par (if not greater) with Park Hyatt. Our room had a wonderful view of Shibuya Crossing and the hotel is conveniently located near restaurants, Shibuya, and the metro. The room was large and well appointed. Just two flaws: lipstick mark on a pillow and some stains on the couch. Yuck. We didn't bother calling down to complain but if we did, I'm sure we would have been taken care of immediately. We picked this hotel over others because there is a pool. However, we were informed there was a charge to use the pool. Another bummer. However, the concierge made up for it by helping us make reservations for the exact same karaoke room they filmed Lost in Translation. How awesome. (Beware the gaijin tax they charge you there. You usually pay by time but they charged us per person as well). Overall, great location, great service, and great value.

These guys know hospitality. The staff was so helpful and accommodating. Our company booked us in an executive level room and they truly pampered us. Special check-in, cool towels, mango juice, and we were able to kick back as they checked us in and enjoy the view from the 35th floor. Breakfast was included with our booking, they had a great variety of foods, all delicious. Get a made to order omelette just to see how perfectly it is made. The pastries are freshly made and delicious. Rooms were spacious and comfortable. The toilet may have been the most amazing thing with its heated seat and bum sprayer!!Gym is good(not great), if they had a few elliptical machines it would be ideal. The pool is perfect for swimming laps. Temperature is perfect, pool length is great. Location is great for me as I had business in the area. A short walk away is the Shibuya shopping district. That was fun to see at night. Delicious food and lots of people.

This hotel is ideally positioned to Shibuya crossing for exploring Tokyo. The railway and subway station is in walking distance.Try to get a room in an higher level - a gordeous view is garanteed (see my pictures).The breakfest is good but too expensive for children between 13 to 15 years (JPY 3.400).The rooms are nice, soft beds, clean and a big bathroom. But the safe is too little.The room temperatue is ok but just in the floor and in the elevators it is too hot!

We recently stayed 3 nights at the end of our 2 weeks in Japan and this was a beautiful hotel. Great location near Shibuya Station and shops and restaurants. Lovely sized room and sitting on the bed looking at Mt Fiji was very cool although it did only show itself once. Amazing service and very convenient for the bus service to Narita and Haneda Airports. I would highly recommend this hotel.

Efficient and nice hotel. The rooms are big and clean. 5 * standard .However one has to know that the bathrooms in this hotel are not heated which was a rather unpleasant experience as I went there end of March where the outside temperatures are still very low. The Lobby is constantly overcrowded and seats are only available in the coffee shop. All in - a good hotel

This is a local 5 star presumably owned by the Tokyu corp since this is part of the nameThe good:- good location next to shibuya station and the shibuya crossing- rather large room by japanese standards with high view of the city. Also has shower stall which i prefer over the safety hazard tub- good japanese service in general- 2 choices/locations for breakfast, buffet and japaneseNot so good:- concierge does the minimum for you. If my restaurant request is not available, they don't offer alternatives. Just want you to go away. Happened twice- the tv is defaulted with japanese voiceovers for international channels like CNN. Have to figure out how to switch that function off- they issue breakfast and gym coupons. Time to save trees and use the computers for such things- gym is ok, but no elliptical machines5 star local brand. International 5 stars do much better

This is definitely a five star luxury hotel in Japan. Centrally located in Shibuya. 5 min walk to Shibuya station. Hotel staffs are very nice and helpful, service is very goodI was complaining the air con in the room was too hot due to the hot weather. They immediately came in to help and fixed and lower the temperature for me. I used to stay at Keio hotel in Shinjuku, but I will never go back again. I will definitely stay at this hotel when I return to Tokyo.The only down side for this hotel is: whenever you are tired and need to carry stuffs and go back to hotel, if you are coming from Shibuya central/train location, you need to walk to a cross bridge and then a uphill in order to go back to hotel- but only 5 mins walk.

The hospitality at the Cerulean Tower Hotel was great The staff was firiendly and very helpful and the rooms clean and of decent size. The Location is great - just off Shibuya Station. The really bad flaw is the extremely slow Internet Connection. It was not possible for me to work at all.

Great hotel in the shibuya area, 5 mins from the train station, fantastic view from the large hotel window, stayed on the 33rd floor for three nights, 105000 yen, a bit expensive, but it was the end of the holidays and it was a relief to have a decent size room,

Accessibility at its best. Just 10 minutes walk away from the main train station. 5 minutes walk away from great eateries. If you are into Michelin grade of dining, Legendary Chinese Iron Chef, Chen Kenichi has his restaurant here in Cerulean Tower Shibuya. Enough said about the dining and location, the most important thing about Hotel: Service.Almost perfect. All hotel staffs are well-trained, attentive and courteous. Always there to attend your needs. When in tokyo, i always stay in a popular hotel in shinjuku (K*******P******) but recent frustrations that the hotel gave me, made me discover this fantastic hotel in Shibuya. Cerulean Tower Hotel........You just got yourself a regular customer! Woo Hoo! Oh...Before i forget, the stunning view from hotel room window, is simply fantastic.

Had a wonderful stay at the Cerulean back in April 2017. The location is extremely convenient, especially to Shibuya Crossing. The statute of Hachiko is also very close by. We were able to walk to almost everything (although sometimes it was a bit of a way, but we liked to walk). Highly recommend. Our JTB tour also picked us up from the lobby. Unfortunately, concierge was not able to secure the more desirable sushi restaurants, we were a couple of days late from the 30 day deadline for most.

If you're a fan of Tokyo Drift, or have always wanted to see the rooftop football field featured in the movie, staying at Cerulean actually gives you a view of it from the room! Just make sure you ask for a room from which you can see Tokyu Toyoko department store, right next to Shibuya Station.The hotel has many perks for the business traveller coming to Tokyo for the first time: - great connection: close to Shibuya train station for getting around easily; direct airport limousine bus connection (only 1030 JPY each way, but you won't get a receipt when taking it from the hotel to Haneda)- close to several icons so you can squeeze in some sightseeing: the rooftop Adidas futsal field, Hachiko, Shibuya scramble crossing (go to the overhead bridge linking Shibuya MarkCity to the station for a great perch to take video/photos of the crossing)- next to lively Shibuya with its many restaurants and shops- easy access to foodhalls in Shibuya MarkCity and Tokyu department store where you can stock up on Japanese pastries, dessert and snacks as gifts for the office or just to bring home to family Japanese service standards are phenomenal, so expect that at Cerulean too. I asked for recommendations to ramen and local cuisine near the hotel. The staff came back later with 2 marked maps showing the location of recommended restaurants and even the price range.The rooms are also rather large (by Japanese standards), and yes, you do have to pay for the fitness facilities (I got a free voucher but it was wasted on me).

This is a very nice hotel situated close to Shibuya station. The superior king room is spacious and modern, with a sweeping view of the city. The staff are generally very friendly but I met some miscommunication issues due to the staff's level of English, so do make sure your question gets across to the staff clearly to avoid misunderstanding. It should also be noted that there may be a fee charge for using the sports facility if you are not staying at the executive floor. Otherwise, wonderful location very close to lively Shibuya!

We last stayed here a few years ago, and this visit the hotel looked even nicer than the first time. They have done a great job of maintaining this property which is in the heart of Shibuya within a 3 minute walk to the train station. The rooms were very nice with great views of the city (get the bathroom with the window over the tub) and the service is always wonderful. If you're a frequent Tokyo visitor, you know how nice it is to have a 7-11 tucked on the second floor of the building for easy ATM's, snacks, and whiskey highballs in a can. We had drinks a couple of times at the Italian restaurant on the second floor--go see Sunny at the bar, he's awesome.As for location, I just don't think you can do much better in Tokyo than the Cerulean. Shibuya is fun to walk around, and it's also a super easy walk to Harajuku, Aoyoma, and Naka Meguro. The train station is big enough that you can get everywhere easily, including catching the NEX to the airport and the Shinkansen to Kyoto, etc. I've looked at pricier hotels that look super swank, but they just aren't located all that great, and the Cerulean feels way nicer than its price. One last thing--I contacted the concierge a few months out about restaurant reservations, and they got us in to Sukiyabashi Jiro in Ginza. That was a major thumbs up, and I highly recommend their concierge service for your tough to get in restaurant needs.

We took our son for his 18th birthday celebration to Tokyo - his first visit. I had heard that the Cerulean hotel in Shibuya is a good bet. Not in the middle of the frenetic footfall but close enough to be near the cool factor. The hotel is certainly well located and the price point is value for money. We took a large corner room that was huge and great for lounging. It was the little things that let us down. The stuffy bedrooms even after maintenance checked it twice. The lack of turn down service. The fact that the massage service could only be booked from 4pm and you could only contact them from 4pm. The knowledgeable but unwelcoming concierge service. The weak hairdryer. It was like they got the architecture right but the experience of hotel guests was an overthought. Which is fine in a business hotel where harried guests just want a wake up call and an early breakfast. By any other standards, it was a good stay. But this is my 8th trip to Japan, where the level of courtesy (from bellboys to random strangers helping you find your way on the street) and hotel service makes every other guest relations officer look like a warden keeping discipline in a super max prison. So for Japanese standards it was a let down.

This being another one of my regular business stops with work crew never fails to please. Consistent Japanese warm and charming hospitality.Rooms are great and always immaculate and nothing is ever too much trouble.Great location in Shibuya and some really great places for eats just a minute or two walk away. Highly recommend.

After a week of vacationing in Japan, I returned to the Cerulean for the last couple of nights. I now realize the service is just average for Japan and the cost is very high. The concierge was not at all helpful when I asked for a jazz club recommendation. Just told me their own club was closed on a Saturday night for a private event. The drinks at the roof top bar were overpriced and just average. This is still probably the best hotel in Shibuya, but it's not value for money.

The room was large enough for the three of us and an extra twin bed was setup in the for our teen. This room is expensive for the size but I don't think an extra bed would've fit in a standard room. Very comfortable beds and pillows with down comforters. The room was quiet and we had an amazing view. The bathroom was extra large with a view as well and shower with a large tub. It cost extra to use the gym but if you arrive before 7am it's free. Location is great - right up the hill from Shibuya station and right in the hustle of things. 7-11 right in the building. The bar at the rooftop had delicious drinks at a premium price (1450 Yen). I would definitely come back and maybe book two standard rooms with a view to see if it costs less than their corner room.

We stayed here a week and used it as our home base, traveling all around the area. T's a fine accommodation for the price, would go again. The concierge is very useful in making reservations, but some of the recommendations we're just OK, I'd suggest researching where you want to go.

We unfortunately had to cancel our reservation at the Cerulean, booked with the website Agoda. We had a really difficult time with Agoda, and put undo pressure on the hotel too. As we were getting the runaround from Agoda, I visited the hotel directly and discussed the issue with them. They were kind enough to cancel. We look forward to our next opportunity to stay at the hotel!

The location of this hotel is the best thing about it, without a doubt. Very easy access to the station and the shops of Shibuya. We had a standard room on the 26th floor, and because Tokyo is so vast, I suspect the views are equally incredible regardless of which side of the building they're on.The hotel is what one would expect of a business hotel in a city - nothing special, although having seen a number of 4* hotels with extremely small bathrooms and rooms in Tokyo I was a bit worried, but this was not a problem here. As it's pretty standard though, I just wanted to share a few 'be aware' notes:- We booked on Hotels.com which is usually really good at small print, but the hotel had not told them (I guess) that there was an additional charge - I think about Y2000 ppn - to use the pool and gym. I was extremely angry because it was one of the reasons we booked that hotel, and they were not even slightly apologetic. However, on pushing a bit, we were told that signing up to a Japanese hotel loyalty scheme they would give us free access for the duration of our stay - well worth doing!- The bar on the top floor - like many upmarket hotel bars in Tokyo, we later discovered - charged a cost just to be seated, even for guests. This was fairly pricey, so just be aware if you want to go and take in the view of the crossing (which is pretty cool, but not worth the price of two extra cocktails when you can just walk up there and take a look!). They also didn't do nibbles with drinks, which seemed unnecessarily stingy!- The restaurants attached to the hotel are - unsurprisingly - really expensive, but the one we went to (the Italian) was not worth it at all. We only went there because it was late and we needed to eat, but in hindsight should have just crossed the street!- The hotel pool does not allow access to people with tattoos! We'd heard about this for the onsen (although saw no signs or evidence of a ban), and were very surprised that it was the case for a business hotel in the city, but there you go - consider yourselves warned!

We booked 2 rooms and stayed for 6 nights there. Impressive hotel with a spacious room. Great facilities in the hotel except we didn't try the pool as a lot of reviews we read stated that they are charged. Hotel staffs are quiet friendly and helpful ( most of them tried to communicate with us efficiently ).For people with kids, the hotel is not really located at the famous Shibuya crossing (it is a 10 minutes walk ).

The Cerulean Tower Hotel is in a great location close to Shibuya station and the famous busy Shibuya crossing. It is a vibrant busy area with lots of shops and diverse places to eat. The sky lounge is a great place to grab a drink and admire the view from the 40th floor!The view from our room on the 24th floor was also quite spectacular. Apparently on a clear day (unlikely in early summer) we could have even seen Mt Fuji! The room was very spacious for Tokyo and the bed was huge and very comfortable. The bathroom was spacious, but could have done with a bit more space for placing your personal toiletries. I enjoyed the large bath. The one thing that really let it down was a pervading smell of cigarette smoke in our non-smoking room. I couldn't tell if the precious occupant had been smoking or if it had been circulating from smoking rooms via the air conditioning. As a non-smoker and an asthmatic it was quite noticeable. I would have asked to be moved but I suspected it was an air articulation issue as it was worse on the second day, so moving likely wouldn't have made much difference.However, the standard of cleanness was very high and the staff were friendly and helpful, so overall it was a pleasant stay.

Nice high end hotel with spacious rooms offering a great view. Very convenient location next to the train station in Shibuya. For being this type of hotel, I'd say it has somewhat a personal charm, with a fancy sky lounge bar with fantastic view.Gym and pool is unfortunately not included in the room rate, but is charged extra each day. The additional charge is in my view too high, and I would expect the gym to be included in a business hotel.The pillow are awfully weird though; traditional Japanese bean bag pillows.

Beautiful hotel in Shibuyia, caters to businessmen, spacious comfortable rooms, spotless bathrooms with tub and shower with excellent water pressure. Very efficient service. Bedding was soft, room service arrived timely in the middle of the night, and both western style buffet and Japanese breakfast were excellent if pricey. There is money exchange and 7/11 with ATM machine on premises.Location is close, actually next to shibuya scramble and views from top floors are amazing, especially for sun rising.All staff is polite and helpful to a fault. Helped us with directions, shipped our luggage to kyoto for us.Enjoyed our stay very much and would one back gladly.

This was a wonderful hotel to stay in. The room as well as the bathroom were very roomy. They provide everything you might need from razors, brushes, toothbrushes, and a full refrigerator. The only thing that was not in the room was a hair drier. Sitting on a warm toilet seat for the first time was a surprise!! We had a wonderful view of Tokyo and were close to subway stations and shopping. The breakfast buffet had a wide range of Japanese and American choices. They even squeezed fresh orange juice!

Nice and clean hotel with a bit more personality than a typical Hilton etc. The bar and café on ground floor are nice. But stay away from the Japanese restaurant in the hotel. It was an over priced disappointed that made loose my faith in Japanese cuisine. Thanks to the concierge we found a super restaurant (Rakushokshu Maru) the day after that was the complete opposite. Go there instead, only 5 min in a taxi.

While on a recent trip to Tokyo visiting our son, we stayed at the Cerulean Tower Tokyu Hotel. This is a wonderful hi-end Tokyo hotel, centrally located to the nearby subway system, popular night spots and dining establishments. The rooms were nicely appointed, clean, with beautiful views of the city. The staff was efficient, helpful, and always available for any need. It is equipped with banquet facilities as well with a wedding taking place during one day of our stay. There are several eating and drinking establishments within the hotel, including a roof-top one with beautiful views of the city. Narita Airport has a shuttle which will provide direct transportation to and from the Cerulean Tower Hotel for approximately $30 per person. This is a beautiful hotel which I would recommend to families or businesses alike for any type of stay in the greater Tokyo area.

Loved our stay here. We got the executive suite and had access to the lounge which was very handy. We had 1 breakfast in the main buffet but then had a lighter breaky in the lounge the rest of the time. Loved happy hour drinks there too each night. The hotel room was massive and had everything we needed. Very professional staff and the location was convenient and close enough to the station without having to be right in shibuya city.

We got a 44m2 room as we were in Tokyo for 12 days, the extra price was worth it for the space. High floor, great views (even from the bath). The staff are awesome and Shibuya is a great area to stay, the train station is 5 mins walk. The restaurants in the hotel are incredible, we tried 3 and each was fantastic although the rest of the time we went out and got a bit more "local". It is expensive, and the food and restaurants were top dollar, but you do get top quality in return, so overall well worth it.

During the Tokyo FilmFestival we stayed at this hotel. It was close to the Bunkamura building in Shibuya where the festival was held. First good thing was that therfe was every day a free busride the whole day from n to the festival. The room was very good n big. Good service also at the breakfast. Clean bathroom. Friendly employees. Great view. Also a good busservice pick up n drop to n from the airport.

An oasis of calm, right next to busy Shibuya crossing. This is a very well priced 5-star hotel. Food and drinks are expensive as expected, but there are many places nearby. You can use ATM at the nearby 7-11, as most ATMs do not accept US or Canadian bank cards. Rooms are large and well appointed.

This hotel is at a great location within Tokyo. You will be at walking distance of restaurants, shopping and parks. The view is also amazing at night. The staff is great and very helpful. There is a shuttle (airport limousine) from Narita Airport directly to this hotel and back. The round-trip is $50. Well worth it since the trip lasts 1.5 hours each way. Going to this hotel will save you a lot of logistic headache which you might not want to get when you travel abroad. The whole staff was really good at English too.

Shibuya is home to a lot of must see attractions in Tokyo and to be within a 5 minute walk from the station was quite handy. Be warned, Shibuya Station is VERY big and finding the correct exit was a bit of a mission however if you ask attendants at the station they are usually very happy to help. A 5 minute walk, albeit a bit of trek with our luggage as there are quite a few overpasses to cross and a little bit of an incline. But once checked in, it was very convenient. The hotel is very clean, the room was a large room for Japan standards. We stayed here as a family of 4 and were provided with 2 twin beds. Stayed on the 23rd floor and the views were absolutely breathtaking. The bathrooms were also immaculate and all toiletries were provided, however we did have to request an iron as one was not provided. The buffet breakfast was priced at roughly AUD $40 per person which was a bit pricey, however they had a chef preparing eggs and traditional Japanese breakfast as well as continental and American. I would just stroll into Shibuya for a huge selection of bakeries and cafes!!There's also a family mart just around the corner so you can pick up a few things to snack on too. All in all a great hotel in a great location.

great location next to the Shibuya canter you can walk and go to everywhere there is a lot of near train station really kind service the room was clean and nice the room service arrived on time and was really good the room was bigger then other hotel room in the area

Great hotel, central and good price quality. Japanese staff is really friendly! View is amazing over the city! Breakfast is great. Choosing between Japanese and western. Third time here! If you want to have a 5 star as mandarin or Four Seasons it's 2 times as expensive.

Our first time in Tokyo and we were pleased we picked this hotel, we got the limo bus straight there from Narita. The front desk staff were very helpful and kind to us with our limited Japanese.The rooms were quite big for Tokyo from what I have heard and our room was and had a great view of the city.Went up to the 40th floor for drinks with an even better view! This hotel was so central the train is only 5 minutes away and restaurants are everywhere. We walked to a lot of places like Harajuku yoyogi park as it's easy to walk there.

All I can say is WOW! From the moment we walked in I knew this place was special. We stayed here for 3 nights for my 40th birthday and would have to be one of the best hotels I've ever stayed in. Usually we stay in an airbnb or cheaper hotel but thought we would splurge and it didn't disappoint..We got an upgrade too which was awesome! The room and bathroom were big and the bed was so comfortable and the view from the room was to die for. People spend big money for those views it's good to sit and have a drink and watch the sunset over Tokyo.If your thinking of spending money on a beautiful hotel with killer views and want to stay in Shibuya than this place is perfect..HIGHLY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!

This is my second time staying at the Cerulean Tower hotel in two years. My favorite things about the hotel include the beautiful unobstructed views. If you get a room with a window facing southwest, you can see Mt Fuji on a clear day! It's a great view to wake up to. The hotel is very close to Shibuya station and it makes getting around Tokyo a breeze. Their in-house dinning and afternoon tea are good as well

My husband and I spent a week at the Cerulean Tower and had an excellent experience. We spent a lot of time in Shibuya and this was conveniently located in that neighborhood. (Also walkable to Shimokitazawa, Naka-megura, and Daikanyama, where we spent a good deal of time). The room was a good size and clean. The staff was very helpful and helped coordinate a plan to send our luggage to our next hotel while we traveled to Kyoto. After busy days of sightseeing it was so nice to return to a neighborhood we loved. We could casually wander Shibuya for an hour or so without it becoming a stressful thing. We also really enjoyed getting drinks at the bar at night. Great view. It was a five minute walk to Shibuya Station which was such a hub. So many lines ran through there. Later in the trip we stayed at the Park Hyatt and though that is a beautiful hotel, there wasn't much to do in the neighborhood and the nearest subway station wasn't that conducive to easy travel around town. We had to transfer a lot and it was confusing. We missed the Cerulean Tower!

We stayed two nights in room 3310 and had a great time here. The rooms were pretty big for Tokyo and we had a fantastic north view of Tokyo. We could see the high rises of Shinjuku, Shibuya crossing from our window, Tokyo tower and Skytree. Rooms were clean and staff were excellent. On our last day we also enquired if we could use the showers in the evening after our check-out and were happy to hear that we could. The shower facility was outstanding was helpful prior to our long flight. Ps: Make sure to use the massage chairs - they are awesome. We thought it was a nice touch for them to allow us to use the showers and not charge us - it was greatly appreciated. Although the location is really close to Shibuya - it does require some walking on the overhead bridges and with heavy luggages or kids etc. this would become a pain. But we didnt mind this considering how great the hotel was. Internet was blazing fast also.

Very nice Hotel with very nice welcoming staff. Large lobby with many people going around . My room was on the 27th floor with a lovely view. I had a clean and specious room for two with a very nice bathroom. I booked room only and Breakfast was optional, so I have no idea what the hotel offered for breakfast. If I am not mistaken Breakfast was in access of 3000 yen per person. I paid in access of 30'000 yen per person per night room only. The hotel is located very central in Shibuya area with walking distance to the center. It is also walking distance from Shibuya central train / metro station. Shibuya is a nice shopping area with lots of restaurants & cafes. You can also reach Shibuya from Narita Airport directly via the Narita Express train.One last comment communication in English with most of the staff was fine not perfect They try hard.

I don't understand some of the negativity I've read about this hotel, but here's my opinion. We arrived really early today so the friendly reception lady apologised that our room wasn't ready yet for check-in. But she offered to take our luggage and asked if we'd like to use the shower, sauna and pool facilities in the meantime to get refreshed after our long flight, for free of course. So we did and afterwards we went out for a little shopping. When we returned the bell-girl raced to us as we entered the lobby to tell us our room was ready and if she needed to collect our luggage. She was super friendly, just as the reception lady! Our room is on the 30th floor, with an amazing view of the bay area. Sure the hotel is a little older, so it isn't as up to date with it's design as the Marriott Miyako in Osaka for example, but still, the room is nice, spacious and clean and the bathroom is beautiful. I have nothing bad to say about this hotel.It's big, friendly, clean, high-class and it's location is brilliant.

This modern hotel is truly delightful. The staff are friendly and courteous, although English is not broadly spoken. The facilities at the hotel include a gym and a swimming pool, ballroom and much, much more. The rooms are spacious and have a breathtaking view of Tokyo city. The room, bathroom and toilet receive top marks from me. Attention to detail is superb. Centrally located, this hotel is close to many central city attractions.Do not overlook an opportunity to experience what this hotel has to offer!

Everything about this hotel was perfect. Friendly and helpful staff, beautiful large rooms and the views from the higher floors are incredible. The location is perfect for nearby restaurants and the metro. I will definitely stay here when visiting Tokyo again.

Everything was perfect in this hotel, I enjoyed my staying here except few things:Pros:- Location: 5 mints walk to Shibuya station. And 6 mints from Shibuya Crossing the busiest in the world.- Rooms are in good condition, very clean and organized.- Very friendly staff.- Great lobby.- Escalators in the entrances that will help you when you carry your luggage.- Comfort beds and pillows.Cons:- Chargeable facilities!! Yes ! you have to pay to use the hotel GYM or POOL. This is so wired in 2017!
user_name:
Khalaqi
Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

review_body: I always stay here on Business when I am in town. It is walkably convenient to the Shibuya + Shibuya station where you can quickly get the Nex to the airport. The hotel room is spacious, clean and simple. The bar upstairs is a great place to grab and drink to unwind at the end of the day and watch the busy pedestrian intersection/all of Tokyo. The continental breakfast downstairs is nice but extremely expensive ($30 US I believe) and the internet is typically very reliable. If you can ask for a room that faces Mt Fuji, on a clear day it will sit right in the center of your window!

We stayed at Cerulean Tower on our recent trip to Japan. First for 4 nights and then again our last night in Tokyo in a different type of room (notes on both below). Overall the hotel is really nice, but definitely a business hotel. It's located very close to Shibuya Crossing and the train station--you become very intimately acquainted with the overpass bridge to go back and forth from the hotel to the train. The location is key as many trains stop here and you can get almost anywhere with this as a starting point. The concierge was not as helpful as would have liked though. I expected quick recommendations but they looked things up online and one time suggest a restaurant in a mall food court (for the record there's nothing wrong with food court restaurants but this one was not very good and it was my husbands birthday).Our first room, room 3318 on the 33rd floor. Great room--small and very clean. There is a large window that you can look out while laying on the bed and we had a view of Mt Fuji (when it wasn't hazy). Comfy bed, hard pillows (one of which has weird pearl type things in it, I didn't like it when sleeping on my side). Medium sized bathroom, nice L'Occitane amenities, no counter space. You have to use your room key to access this floor (which makes you feel special) and you get free breakfast in the morning which was insanely helpful every day. Breakfast is good, not great. LOVE the coffee/latte machine! Free internet was ok, worked but couldn't stream anything (that's probably the point).Our second room, 2208 (I think that was the number). Very clean much bigger than the other room. It had the biggest bed I've ever seen in my entire life! The bed was very comfy with ok pillows (same as other room). The bathroom was quite large, tons of counter space and a separate "room" with the shower tub. This shower did not have an "American" shower where the shower head is over the tub with a shower curtain. We stood in the tub while holding the shower head over us. Amenities are good but not L'Occitane. The thing that killed me in this room was that if you need an iron, you have to rent it from the hotel. The other room had an iron in it. No special room key access for this floor, makes you feel like a plebian when you're in the elevator with someone who has special floor access. Had a view of Tokyo Tower which was great! No breakfast with this room but that was fine because we were going to the fish market for breakfast. Free internet was ok, worked but couldn't stream anything (that's probably the point).Overall, I would stay here again in Japan and recommend it to others.

I stayed here with my 11 year old daughter for a week before venturing on to Kyoto... we were extremely pleased with the facility and especially the location. We were upgraded to a room on a higher floor with views of Tokyo and Mt, Fuji in the distance. Staying here was an excellent choice and we look forward to coming back on our next trip to Japan.

Stayed there with a group for a trade show. The place is bustling and efficient as well as near various shopping areas. Had ordered from Amazon Japan and the box was promptly handed to me as I checked in. The luggage service was prompt and pleasant. We had opted to splurge on a room with access to the 33rd floor executive lounge instead of doing the group rate. The room we had turned out to be smaller than one of the rooms for the group and more expensive but bed and pillows were super comfortable.. The executive lounge is a treat though with great views including Mt. Fuji on a clear day. The people in the lounge couldn't have been more helpful. Breakfast there was lovely. Afternoon tea was meager as far as food but great if you happened to be a big drinker as booze is free of course.My one complaint: when we checked in they advised they were totally sold out and although the room was quite small and there were stains on the carpet, we were too tired to say anything. I expected that the stains would be taken care of by the next day but nothing was done. As we were there for business, we were seldom in the room and only thought to mention it as we checked out. They apologized but said no adjustment could be made as we had not advised earlier. I found that surprising and disappointing considering we had stayed there 9 nights.

Stayed here 3 nights. Payed 330$ per night (including one way transfer to Narita airport for 2 persons) for a king size bed room (booked through Booking.com and changed 3 times with no charge as the price went down) and were upgraded to a higher floor which was very nice of them. It is centrally located in Shibuya, close to the night life, near the train station and the subway (extremely easy to learn and commute - everything is in English), walking distance to chic neighborhoods, Izakayas and restaurants. The hotel's concierge did a great job making reservations and recommending where to eat, excellent service, comfortable pleasant rooms, nice view, good bathroom with nice products. This hotel is run very well! Next time in Tokyo will definitely stay here again!

Stayed here for two nights, at the end of a short visit to Tokyo. We stayed here two years ago and loved it, but the price had increased substantially since then , so we opted to stay first at the Ecxcel Tokyo this time, with just our last two nights here.Really loved the amazing service as soon as you approach reception. The hotel seems to have a swarm of people to serve you as soon as you arrive, and the staff are genuinely friendly and helpful. We stayed in a twin room on the 20th floor, and had a huge corner room which was very light and bright.Our only concern was the strange noise which periodically came from the bathroom throughout our stay. We couldn't work out whether this was someone flushing a toilet or emptying a bath on another floor, but it was certainly a loud noise. We didn't worry too much about this though.The breakfast buffet was reasonably expensive ( around A$40 pp ), but quite good, with freshly squeezed orange juice, good pastries, and all the usual breakfast options. If I was deciding on future bookings whether or not to pay a breakfast inclusive rate, I'd probably opt for no breakfast, as it was nice to do for a couple of days, but after that I think I'd just head to Starbucks where you can get a reasonable coffee, fruit, yoghurt with granola and a juice for around $15-$20 pp.All in all, this is a really nice hotel with a great location, but if the price keeps escalating, I'd go to the Shibuya Excel which is considerably cheaper.

Great hotel and strategic position, friendly and helpful staff. Most interestingly they speak English and they work hard to communicate with best of the ability. To all my request they able to provide accurate information. Good spread for breakfast and dinner.

This is a great location for visiting the Shibuya area. Everything is spotless which is typical for Japan. The only negative I can give is that I was never able to decipher the TV remote so I was able to reach the CNN station but could never get any sound.

This is our third visit to Tokyo and after staying in Marunouchi and Shinjuku before we decided we liked Shibuya the best. We had a Japan Railpass so in one way it doesn't matter that much which area you choose as you can use the JR Yamanote line to traverse the city (the subway lines are not included in the JR pass). We had prebooked the Airport Limousine Bus which goes directly from Haneda Airport to this hotel but as our flight was late and we ended up arriving after midnight so we could not use our prebooked ticket. There was a night bus we used but we had to pay again for it - so if you are arriving in the evening i wouldn't prebook the bus - it is easy to do at the airport anyway.This hotel is 5 star and we had a sky view room that gave us wonderful views of Tokyo - so no need to go up Tokyo Tower. It is a 3 minute walk to JR Shibuya station but there is an overpass and lots of steps. We had an enormous king sized bed and the bathroom was large with good toiletries. Some welcome biscuits on arrival were delicious. All staff we met were efficient and polite. On check out we discovered the individual filter coffee cups provided in the room were not free and so we were charged - it was not that expensive but if we'd known we had to pay extra we probably would not have used them - this was not made clear in the room.

This is a very nice upmarket hotel, conveniently located in the Shibuya area close to the shops, train station etc. Our room on the 29th floor was very comfortable and had a great view. There is a convenient bus shuttle service to the airport. One of the selling points for us when booking the hotel had been the pool and gym. We were surprised to discover when we arrived that there was an extra charge for using these facilities (a bit more than 2000 yen per day) and that the pool is not accessible to children under 18.

This hotel has immediate access to the people bridges taking you directly to Shibuya Station. It is also very close to a fabulous grocery market "Food Show" which carries foods from all over the world. I was traveling with my daughter and the Food Show was a must stop almost everyday.

Attentive staff, excellent service. Rooms are large and comfortable. Everything is up to date and clean. Room service great as well as massage service. Elevators are quick and clean. In room utilities bath and shower are great

We had booked at the cerulean tower as our stay in Tokyo. We had chosen this hotel as we were doing a lot of travelling inbteo weeks.The premise behind booking here was for comfort and 5 star service.On arriving it was not even acknowledged that it was my special birthday, despite my husband e mailing on booking to ensure the hotel were aware. We then discover, that to use the bar on the top floor demanded a service charge to sit at a table, despite that we were staying there. Not only the disappointments so far, we headed to the gym to work out and have a nice leisurely swim. To our astonishment, we had to further pay to use these facilities! In all my time of extensive world travel at 5star hotels have I ever come across this situation. It is should be made clear on booking that this is the case.We had many friends meeting us there for drinks, it was costly to pay cover charge to sit at a table each time..The hotel bedrooms are in need of modernisation. It's dated.Save your self a penny or two and book elsewhere.

I stayed at the Cerulean tower hotel on a business trip .Room s large , perfect for westerners, large bathrooms and plush bathrobes & towels.Many restaurants to choose from, I would like to thank the staff on the 40th floor lounge for their service and friendliness as well as the fabulous view of Shibuya from the bar.

Service was excellent and communication was very easy in English. Rooms (at least the two we stayed in) were large, clean, and comfortable. Location is pretty much unbeatable – just a few minutes’ walk to Shibuya station and tons of food, drink, and shopping. The bar on the top floor has fantastic views of the city but (as expected) drinks are expensive and there is a cover charge (at least later in the evening). Only complaint was that internet was really, really slow. Was faster to just use our wireless data plan. Otherwise a 5 star experience.

Stayed here for one night in a family adjoining room. It wasn't cheap at nearly $800 but the room was great and the location even better. It's a 3 min walk from the Shibuya station which was excellent as we arrived via train from Kyoto and took the Nex train to Narita from the same station. We arrived 2 hours earlier than the check in time and they managed to expedite our room so we could check in early. We had a fabulous view of the city from our 20th floor rooms. Great pressure in the shower, comfy beds, delicious in room coffee and a nice sitting area to relax. We also enjoyed the gift of complimentary cakes left in the room. The only downside is that kids under 12 are not allowed in the fitness area or pool even with an adult so our 9 year old was very disappointed. Would recommend and would stay here again.

Great location and good facilities.The hotel is walking distance from Shibuya station and the world famous scramble crossing.I highly recommend this hotel for its excellent location and quality facilities.

The location of this hotel is ideal, just south of the Shibuya Crossing and the major train station. It's a quick walk over the pedestrian bridge into Shibuya and all the restaurants and nightlife. But be warned, with luggage it's a haul, especially after a long flight. Best to take the Limousine Bus which drops you right at the hotel. The hotel is also great proximity to some more residential neighborhoods for more quaint cafes and restaurants (Tomigaya and Daikanyama neighborhoods are worth a visit). The views from the hotel are outstanding, especially from the top floor bar. It's expensive but worth a drink, especially on a Saturday night when you have prime view of the Shibuya Crossing.We had a corner room which was very large for Tokyo standards. It had a large bench seat along the picture window that our 4 year old would play at for hours, taking in the views. The beds are double beds, which are small by American standards but manageable. The bathroom was luxurious and again had fabulous views.The service was top notch. Emails prior to arrival were promptly answered. We accidentally left our daughter's stuff animal behind and housekeeping located her prized possession and quickly mailed it to us. We couldn't ask for a better stay and would certainly stay here again.

This hotel was is in an ideal location in Shibuya. 5 min walk from the Shibuya station that connects you to anywhere. With that said, you are surrounded by shops and restaurants. The rooms are spacious and comfortable. The bathroom was great, the tub faces a huge window, over looking Tokyo. Cons: They gave us a smoking room when we reserved a non-smoking. If it was us, its fine but we had a 15 month old with us. We had a traditional Japanese breakfast in the hotel and it was on the pricey end, about $30 USD...not worth it.

I have to say, this was an awesome hotel. The location is great, about a 5 minute walk from the Metro and there are quite a few dinner/lunch options from here, but the hotel was class all the way. I don't know if this hotel is a 5 star hotel but it definitely felt like it. The views from our room were great, the staff couldn't have been nicer and the beds were super comfortable. I think if I were to stay in this area again, this hotel is at the top of my list.
user_name:
domrep122
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Absolutely loved our stay here. We paid about $330/night during a Friday-Sunday stay during cherry blossom season (April 2017). Upon check-in we were upgraded to a corner room as the room type we had reserved was not available. The room was absolutely incredible, with views of all of Tokyo and we could even see Mount Fuji. The bathroom was so luxurious that rather than going out on Saturday night (had stayed out really late Friday night in Shinjuku), I lounged in the beautiful bath overlooking the city. The bed was great, the service was impeccable, the location is amazing - a very short walk to Shibuya Station and an easy walk as well to everything in Shibuya and Harajuku. Highly recommend this hotel and will stay here again if I find myself in Tokyo a second time.

We have chosen this hotel after months of research and planning. Hotel location and accommodations had great reviews. Nightly rate was a little higher than other hotels in the vicinity. However, when planning a family trip, didn't want to save few dollars and be miserable for the duration of the trip. We have booked two queens with the two minors for the room (2 nights). Upon checking-in front desk lady said you need to book an extra room because you have only indicated two adults on reservation. So she reserved an additional room on a totally separate level at additional $500/per night. At this moment, my comment was we are here on a family vacation. You are expecting us to be in two different rooms? How about upgrading to a suite so we can be together? Front desk lady's comment was "we are sold out with suites." She showed no effort to accommodate and when I asked her to cancel the EXTRA room, she threw the credit card back at us. I told her, I would rather find another hotel in the vicinity for the two members of our family than book an additional room here at this hotel. When traveling to a foreign country, I understand there might be a language barrier. However, body language and face expressions are Universal. She was definitely rude. I wish I wrote down her name but my mistake.

Nearby hachiko statue and shibuya crossing road.. Very clean, neat and awesome.. Breakfast at caramelo restaurant and they had a super yummy international menu.. I eat till full... Hahaha.. If you feel hungry at night, you only need a little walk to 7/11 or family mart.. Hope you enjoy to stay at this hotel, like me... :)

I'm 6'4" and I booked this hotel mainly on its reputation for large beds and I wasn't disappointed, easily the most comfortable hotel bed I've slept in for years. I could have been a couple inches taller and my feet still wouldn't be sticking out the end. We got a slight upgrade on arrival, so I can't comment on the standard rooms, but our corner room on the 23rd floor was big by western standards and positively enormous by Tokyo standards. The location is perfect, about 300m from Shibuya station but on the opposite side of the station from the main crossing area, so you can easily avoid the crowds when you are entering and leaving the station. I'd absolutely recommend this hotel, it's great.

We stayed for 4 nights at Cerulean. It's located in a great part of Tokyo to explore the whole city - Shibuya station is about a 10 min walk. Service is great and the rooms are good (big for Tokyo). Its more of a business Hotel but still good for tourists. Food seems to be expensive here but if you are travelling then will most likely hardly eat at the hotel anyway

We had a very good stay at Cerulean. It is very well located, just a short walk from Shibuya station. The room was a very good size and had a fantastic view. The staff were helpful. "Tower hotels" can be a little impersonal but Cerulean did a good job at minimising this.

Spent a week at the hotel on vacation. The location just a few hundred metres from Shinjuku is convenient. The hotel is large, expensive and formal. There are lots of people with frozen smiles to greet you but it has the atmosphere of a posh railway station. The rooms are perfect and the bathroom is all marble. Very little to eat in the hotel and the breakfast options are very sparse unless you go out. There is little warmth in the contact with staff but service is efficient. What really irked me was that in an expensive hotel in Japan (of all places) you are charged an outrageous amount for daily wifi access.

A very good hotel. The breakfast is more than perfect. A lot of choices and very tasty. The pool and jacuzzi perfect. My only compliant is with the executive lounge. The food very basic for the price.A good hotel

Great Place To Stay And Best Location Of Whole Tokyo. Awesome Hotel By Service And Location, Easy Four Stars. Best Hotel In Shibuyan Area. Good Looking Hotel Wich Is Easy To Find And It's Not Too Expensive For Usual People
user_name:
FenixTrips
New York City, New York

review_body: Spent 6 nights at this hotel along with my wife. Location is excellent, 5 min. walk to Shibuya station and scramble crossing. Facility is luxurious, convenient grocery located in the same building, many restaurants as well.Rooms are spacious, big bathrooms and comfortable beds.Staff were friendly and always keen to help.The only take I have on this hotel is the terrible WIFI which you don't expect in a city like Tokyo!!! It was dead slow especially at evening!Quite expensive.

What a fantastic hotel. From the location to the size of the room, it was all amazing. I normally don't stay with big hotels but on this occasion it was well worth it. We booked an executive room and let me tell you it was worth the money. The room size was bigger than anticipated. I was expecting it to be really small but it was quite the opposite, it was massive. Another great feature of this hotel was the view from our room, we had a room facing Shibuya - see photo attached, at night it was something else. Another feature the hotel offered was a "forwarding luggage" facility. You just check your luggage in and they will send it to the next location for you (for a fee). Which was fantastic it meant we could travel luggage free. Overall our experience was fantastic. I would highly recommend this hotel.

We stayed for 3 enjoyable nights in this hotel from April 5th to 7th 2017. We were grateful that the hotel up graded us to the corner room in the club floor. What a pleasant surprise. The view from our bedroom and bathroom were stunning . The bed , sheets , towel were soft and very comfortable.We surely be coming back.

While there are many choices in Tokyo to stay and visit, everyone goes to Shibuiya crossing. You are a stones throw away and hence you are right in the middle of the shopping action. Subway access is also easy and a few minutes by foot. We did not spend much time at the hotel (only nights) but getting to the room with a view of Tokyo Tower and skyline and feet up with a beer, was worth the money spent here. It is not cheap but for the location and service we had from everyone at the hotel, we have no complaints. Couple suggestions. Order your sim card with unlimited internet access before arrival to Japan. Pick up at post office in airport. Works with iPhone, not sure about Android. Make sure you have Whatsapp on every phone of your family before arrival. Your itunes account will not be accessible. Google maps is a must to get around.Know your location in relation to other places you plan to visit before arrival to Japan. It is a very busy city and you will not feel like you have any time to think when you get to the train station to buy tickets. Ginza for shopping !Once again thanks to the hotel team for your effort to make it comfortable, wished your hotel options for food were not so expensive. We in fact only ate out for this reason and had excellent food for much lower costs.

We startet our week in Tokyo at the Cerulean Tower Tokyo Hotel. The hotel is located in Shibuya which is by far a better and easier place to start your first visit to Tokyo compared to Shinjuku. Restaurants, shops, the Shibuya crossing and the station is just minutes away. The hotel is also a good starting point for walking trips to other neighborhoods.The hotel itself was a bit disappointing, especially compared to the price. Got a room on the 19th floor, with a terrace in front of the room which limited the views. The room had classic decoration, good quality furniture and was clean enough. However, nothing special really - this was a pretty standard experience. Can't understand what the five stars are all about. We even had to pay to use a very small fitness room. Nice views from the bar at the top.In total; not a five star hotel, but a good place to stay.

Had the best time staying at this place. Amazing location in the heart of Shibuya. Wonderful staff. Adequate gym, but fine for what I needed. I would wholeheartedly recommend to anyone looking to stay in a buzzy part of Tokyo.

Every traveller has their list of needs and Tokyo is a huge place. For us the Cerulean Towers ticked the boxes- but not without a bit of re-work after we arrived. Once we got sorted we had an excellent stay. I would easily stay here again. We are a family of 3. That is, we travel with a teenager. If you have one you understand. These fascinating creatures have different needs and requirements than others in our species. A new adventure can be life-changing. Afterward you might be amazed to hear them tell friends and family how awesome the trip was because during the experience they seemed to prefer to be anywhere else much of the time. Gotta love 'em. We love dragging our teen around the world, but we also love that they are old enough to entertain themselves at times. That said, sharing a hotel room has reached it's term limit. Beds in Tokyo hotel rooms, it turns out, use "double" and "single" differently. And getting a room for 3 is a non-starter. If you are a couple you will have 2 beds (a double). A single is one bed, small or large. We arrived to our room after exchanging emails asking to have our room prepared for 3 only to discover a chaotic nightmare of beds/tables/chairs crammed together to suit our request. Sharing a room with a teen for a week is daunting enough. This was going to break even the most unified of families. Luckily, Cerulean Towers rose to the occasion. We sifted our reservation to two rooms, a single room and double, which ended up costing only slightly more than the "triple". The extra cost made the trip a pleasure for everyone that combined family time with a getaway.  During the day we adventured everywhere by foot and train. The station is not nearly as daunting as I feared. Most things are written in English somewhere. Just leave yourself plenty of time to find your way and figure out the ticket-buying machine. For dinner nearby the hotel there is a hill just behind it that is filled with fantastic tiny Izakaya places, as well as all kinds of other places including Indian and even an American-style diner. We ate at local Japanese places and the food was fabulous and super local.  In-room amenities were excellent which makes packing light. For me that alone almost earns a hotel 5 stars. Razor, toothbrush, toothpaste, as well as the usual shampoo, etc. are all provided and good quality. I was thrilled. But just in case you forgot something, there is a large 7-11 in the hotel and the concierge is fantastic. I had them purchase tickets for me to a museum I wanted to attend (that only sold tix in Japan) and they had them waiting on check-in.  Do stop in the upstairs bar, Bello Visto. The bartender, Park (?) is working on his Aviation which happens to be one of my favorite classic cocktails. They have a good selection of Japanese whiskey and a view that has to be one of the best anywhere in the world.

I highly recommend this hotel it's just a short walk from Shibuya station that will get you anywhere you want to go. The views of Tokyo are extraordinary, the service is great and the rooms are very nice with a huge bath tub to soak in after a long day of touring the city. We will be staying here again when we return!

Good hotel with all the amenities that you would expect. Beds were comfortable and shower had good pressure (considering we were 30 floors up!). Great bar on the 40th for after dinner/pre-bed drinks. We had dinner in the hotel on the first night - which was nice, but expensive and there are lots more eatries around! I found it a bit odd that they charged for entry to the Gym but was very quiet and nicer than running in the crowded streets!

This hotel is in a great location, only a few minutes walk to the famous Shibuya Crossing. From the moment you enter the hotel the service is 1st class, quick check in and your ready to relax. We stayed on the 34th tower floor which gives your entry to enjoy the Executive Salon, this includes breakfast, teatime and evening cocktails. Our room was spacious with beautiful views over shibuya and beyond. The room had an extra large king bed very comfortable, great pillows, good bathroom facilities and the room service is fast. If your thinking of coming to Shibuya this is your place to start your amazing holiday, business trip or just a mini break.

A big hotel with lots of facilities so it does attract the business traveller but don't let this put you off.The staff were very friendly and helpful throughout our stay.The hotel is one of the biggest hotels in the area and is one of the stops from the recommended airport shuttle (limousine bus) which means it's incredibly easy to get to from both airports.The rooms are to a very high standard, large beds with most rooms having a great view across the city. Try to request a room with a view of mount Fuji if you can.There's a bar on the 42 floor that has stunning views across the city and is well worth grabbing a few cocktails there before heading out.The hotel is perfectly situated to make the most of the busy Shibuya area and travelling to other parts of Tokyo via the big station there.Avoid eating at the hotel if you can, it's very expensive and the food is poor. There are a thousand options just 10mins walk away that don't break the bank and have incredible food on offer. Generally speaking it's hard to eat bad food in Tokyo.If you find a place to eat online i'd suggest calling to book because things can get extremely busy especially Thursday/Friday etc.

Location:Walking distance to Shibuya station just have to cross one overhead bridge.From the airport you can board an airport limousine shuttle bus the first stop will be the hotel. Room:Room is clean and huge I booked a room with 2 single bed room is spacious and have a unblock view. The toilet is really spacious.Remark:A great hotel and for the price is a bargain cannot ask for more.

stayed for several nights at this establishment in a room with views to two directions. surprisingly, they claim to be 5 stars but services like gym are not included. western food from room service food was only barely edible. bathroom lacked a fan and became very steamy. if the price was right, i'd consider going back, but there are much better options nearby.

Warm welcome it was, people knew English here it was important for me as I'm a foreigner here. Love the view from my table. Food was tasty too.And ya little expensive. Overall had a nice evening. That's all I have to say I dunno why TripAdvisor want me to write minimum 200 words!

Stayed for five nights and was very enjoyable. The options for both western and Japanese food was very well done. Breakfast buffet was absolutely amazing. The bar on the top level helped take the edge off and had a view of the city.

I spent 3 weeks in Japan last spring & did the rounds with hotels. I stayed at Cerulean Tower my last week there. It's a big hotel in the heart of Shibuya. Shibuya crossing is a few streets away. The hotel is very clean - my room was great, room was big, I was on a high floor so I also had great views. I would recommend Cerulean Tower if you want to be in the heart of everything Tokyo has to offer. Shopping, Restaurants, JR Station and A very cool hidden Sake Bar Alley.
user_name:
filmgirl70
New York City, New York

review_body: This is my second time staying here and it's not changed at all. Excellent, helpful and attentive staff. Tasty and varied breakfast with fresh juices and healthy options.Clean, tidy and well appointed rooms with exceptional views of Tokyo and Shibuya. TV's are a touch dated. Pillows are hard for me but in the cupboard is softer more western style pillows.It's tough to fault this place. Excellent!

If you are lucky enough to go to Tokyo and staying in Shibuya , then spoil yourself and stay at the Cerulean Tower Hotel. We arrived from Narita airport to Shibuya station by Narita express and within minutes we were at the hotel. This was our first trip to Japan and were recommended the hotel and nothing disappointed. The location is great , the staff could not have been any more helpful and obliging. Nothing was a problem and it made our stay even more pleasurable.

A very centrally places hotel for tourists and business traveler alike, Cerulean ticks all boxes. I stayed here for a week for work + leisure and came out highly satisfied at the end of the 7 days. Location (5/5): Located at a 4 min walking distance from Shibuya metro station, Cerulean is just a walk away from the eating and shopping hub that is Shibuya. It's around an hours drive from Narita Airport.Service (5/5): Staff behaves like how a luxury property staff should (I have seen it very less in developed nations). They are courteous and warm and ever so helpful. Most speak English and those who do not try and make sure they understand you and you understand them.Food (4/5):Though I ate here only twice, I was impressed both times. The coffee shop and the Mediterranean restaurant were good. The Chinese restaurant seemed to have a decent spread and the rooftop had a great view. Prices are on the higher side though !Rooms (4/5): The rooms were decently sized. I was lucky to get a room on the 30th floor, overlooking Mt Fuji. The view was mesmerizing during sunsets, and it let me see Mt Fuji every single morning when I woke up right from my bed. The temperature control was effective and fast, the toilet seats were heated, the bathtub and shower were cozy as well. The only low point was the wifi speed, it was terrible to say the least. Luckily they also had an Ethernet connection in the room, the speed for which was decent enough to be used for my work. Check in (2/5): I flew in from a Bombay red eye flight with a total 14 hour door to door commute and expected to just crash in the room. I was told by every single colleague who has taken the same flight and stayed at cerulean that they "do not" give an early check in. Just as expected, I was told to come back to the hotel at 2pm as the room isn't ready yet (I was there at 9am). Check out (5/5): Checkout at 6am was a smooth process and took under 5 minutes. The porter desk also helped arrange tickets for the morning bus back to Narita.Overall, I was super happy with the stay and would definitely want to visit and stay here again. I just wish they allow early check-in and improve their wifi speeds.

We started the trip by getting upgraded to a king size bed room, which was a pleasant surprise with the jetlag coming along. The bed was so nice, and the view was spectacular from our room. The room was large with a very nice bathroom. The toilets was japanese modern with a lot of choices, not the easiest to understand. The breakfast was not included but we payed extra for it and it was really good. I really like the old man who made us the perfect omelettes. The are is also very good and walking distance to the classic Shibuya crossing and restaurants, bars, shopping. Also very close the to subway station.

Wonderful location and easy access to metro. Be sure to take an evening at their top floor bar and watch the sunset, Shibuya Crossing light up, and all the people run about like ants. Lovely rooms, but nothing spectacular. Easy limousine bus transfer to Narita.

A wonderful hotel with excellent accommodations. The staff is very friendly and helpful staff all of whom spoke at least some English. Great location 5-8 minute walk from Shibuya station. Really comfortable beds excess pillows and a very luxurious bathroom with both a shower and tub.

Stayed here for 4 nights last week, the rooms are large for Tokyo standards with a nice bathroom. Service was very good and efficient very much as expected in Japan.The hotel situated about 5 to 7 minutes walk to the Shibuya train and metro stations. To get there, you will need to use the overhead crossing as there is a very busy road directly in front of the hotel. The crossing is not an easy walk for people with mobility issues, but do-able.There's a lot to do in the Shibuya area, with the many restaurants and stores. Don't forget to visiting Hachiko and take the famous Shibuya crossings.

Luxurious hotel, the perfect location, and attentive staff. Loved this hotel because of it's location to the railway, shopping, and restaurants. There is a convenience store near hotel and a Starbucks within walking distance. Great shopping and entertainment area is within walking distance. The rooms are simple but luxurious. If you need to stay in this area of Tokyo for business or pleasure, book this hotel for sure. Cheers!!!

This is a great Hotel to stay if you are wanting to be near Shibuya, the train station is close by, there are a multitude of cool restaurants and shops within easy walking distance. The rooms were a very good size with well equipped bathrooms.I didn't like the idea of having to pay to use the swimming pool, so didn't bother to have a swim.Staff were nice, hotel was very clean.Would stay again if I were in Tokyo.
